introduction.p: Geometry has been well-understood for thousands of years, but there are certain intractable problems in regular Euclidean geometry. One intractable problem was the problem of quadrature.

conjecture.title: The quadrature problem
conjecture.statement: Given a geometric figure, it is possible to construct a square with equal area.

introduction.p: Quadrature seems perfectly reasonable, but is provably the case that with a straight-edge and compass (the two tools of the classical geometer) it is impossible to construct a square with area equal to a given circle; and yet, we all know that the area of the circle of radius r is A=\pi r^2. How is it that we can arrive at this, even in approximation?

subsection.title: Riemann approximation
subsection.p: For the sake of simplicity, we'll consider that the basic problem is to compute the area of the quarter of the unit disk in the first quadrant; that is, the region R bounded by the lines x=0 and y=0 along with the curve y=\sqrt{1-x^2} on the interval 0\leq x\leq 1. This will give us the answer to the classical problem of squaring the circle.

figure.caption: The region R bounded by the lines x=0 and y=0 along with the curve y=\sqrt{1-x^2} on the interval 0\leq x\leq 1

subsection.p: Rectangles are not the only plane figures of which we can determine the area: in fact, since we know the area of a triangle and all rectilinear plane figures can be triangulated, we can find the area of every polygon as a sum of triangular areas. In fact, we'll use trapezoidal regions to approximate the area under the curve. This is a well-balanced balanced approximation, since the trapezoid has as its area A=\frac12(b_1+b_2) h, which is A = \frac12(b_1h+b_2h) the average of two rectangular areas.

figure.caption: An approximation of the quarter-disk by five equal-width trapezoids. Observe how little additional area is outside the approximating region.

statement.p: Let R be a plane region bounded above by the function f(x) and below by the interval a\leq x\leq b on the x-axis.

ol.li: Let n\in\Z^+ be greater than 1. Let a=x_0\lt x_1\lt x_2 \lt \cdots \lt x_{n-1} \lt x_n = b be a regular partition of [a,b], with x_i-x_{i-1} = (b-a)/n for each i\in\set{1,2,\dotsc,n}.
Let y_i = f(x_i) for each i\in\set{0,1,2,\dotsc,n}.
Since the area of the i^\text{th} approximating trapezoid is A_i = \frac12(y_{i-1}+y_i)(x_i-x_{i-1}), the approximate are of R is A(R)\approx \sum_{i=1}^n A_i.

exercise.p: Approximate the value of \pi by approximating the area under the example curve y=\sqrt{1-x^2} using 5 approximating trapezoids, and then 10 approximating trapezoids, and then multiplying by the appropriate factor.
Simplify the expression for A(R) the approximate area using n trapezoids.
